newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish parliament approves cheap fuel for farmers.
newsitem.headline: Polish parliament approves cheap fuel for farmers.

text.p: Poland's lower house of parliament on Friday approved a controversial bill allowing farmers to buy diesel fuel at below-market prices.
The bill, approved in a 262 to 59 vote with 44 abstention, exempts farming diesel from part of the excise tax, now at 460 zlotys per tonne, during the next four years.

During the first year following the implementation of the new regulations, the farming diesel will be exempted from 25 percent of the excise tax, during the second year from 50 percent and then from 75 percent.
The cheap fuel would be coloured and its use for non-agricultural purposes would be prohibited.
The draft needs to clear the senate and be signed by the president to become law.
The bill had been heavily criticed by Grzegorz Kolodko, who quit the post of the finance minister earlier this week, saying he did not want to get pulled into this year's election campaign.
Kolodko had said the draft, which would cost the budget about 600 million in last revenues, would unfairly privilege farmers over other groups.
The Polish Peasant Party (PSL), the smaller group in the ruling leftsit coalition, put forward the bill, saying it would make farm production more profitable and help in the sector's restructuring.
But some analysts have said the bill, if approved, was meant to boost support for the PSL among farmers in parliamentary elections, due in the fourth quarter of 1997.
